Graphical abstract Interaction of hydrogen with model Cu–Zn methanol synthesis catalyst prepared by decomposition of mixed hydroxicarbonate is studied by inelastic neutron scattering, in situ FTIR/MS, and thermal analysis. Reduced (Cu0.08,Zn0.92)O mixed oxide accumulates 6H/Cu, mainly as hydride, hydroxyl and formate species. The reduction of copper in the (Cu,Zn)O mixed oxide occurs via a reversible redox interaction with H2 and absorption of protons as OH−-groups with ν =3250cm−1 and δ ≈1430–1480cm−1. Kinetic and thermodynamic parameters of this process are evaluated. The weight loss during the reduction is due to the decomposition of the residual carbonate groups to CO2 via formate intermediates, which occurs in the presence of hydrogen. Exposure of (Cu,Zn)O to air prior to the reduction strongly affects the kinetic parameters of the reduction process. Keywords Copper–zinc oxide catalyst Copper reduction Hydrogen absorption Inelastic neutron scattering In situ FTIR 1 Introduction Cu–Zn–Al-containing mixed oxide catalysts with ZnO (wurtzite-like) structure are highly active and selective in methanol synthesis. The structure of the oxide is important and the Cu–Zn–Al-containing oxide catalyst with lower Zn:Al ratio and, therefore, spinel-like structure is manifold less active in the route of methanol formation [1]. Solid solutions of copper (and aluminum) cations in the zinc oxide structure can be obtained via low-temperature (not higher than 773–823K) decomposition of Cu(Al)Zn hydroxycarbonates of aurichalcite structure [2,3] to produce OH– and CO3– containing oxide (below denoted as anion-modified or a.m. mixed oxide). The ad-anions provide stabilization of copper cations in the zinc oxide structure, i.e. dissolution of the copper cations in the a.m.-ZnO [4]. At the absence of these ad-anions, perfect ZnO can only dissolve 1% of Cu2+ [5,6], while Cu2+ solubility threshold for a.m.-ZnO is about 10at.% [7,8]. Introduction of 10at.% Al3+ cations helps increasing copper content in the mixed oxide with wurtzite-like structure up to 23at.% in single phase system and even 40% at simultaneous presence of CuO phase [7,8]. Some authors conclude that Cu–Zn(–Al) mixed hydroxycarbonate with aurichalcite clay structure are obligate precursor of the active catalyst for methanol synthesis [9,10], however the preferred structure of industrially relevant precursor is still debated and rosasite (malachite-like) [11] and hydrotalcite-like [12] precursors are proposed. The highest methanol production rates are achieved over Cu-rich catalysts with Cu loading above 50at.%, meanwhile low concentration Cu–Zn(–Al) oxide catalysts derived from aurichalcite or hydrozincite precursors are characterized the manifold higher TOF of methanol formation over metallic copper surface (see e.g. [13]). Therefore, solid solutions of Cu2+ in ZnO structure prepared by decomposition of the corresponding hydroxycarbonates with aurichalcite or hydrozincite structures were chosen as models of methanol synthesis catalysts in numerous studies (e.g. [2,3,7,8,14–18]). At the reaction conditions, the catalyst comprises metallic copper particles epitaxially bound to ZnO structure. The role of ZnO was widely discussed during the last four decades and numerous explanations were proposed for the uniqueness of the Cu–ZnO methanol synthesis catalyst. Among the most substantial are those considering Zn–Cu brass formation and its further surface segregation [19–21], Cu–ZnO interface effects, incl. the impact of Schottky junction [22] and wetting/nonwetting phenomena giving affecting Cu0 particle morphology depending on the redox potential of the reduction gas [15,23]. According to [13], the TOF of methanol synthesis correlates to the lattice strain in the Cu metal phase, which is epitaxially bound to ZnO. The presence of steps at the surface of defective copper nanoparticles with a nearby Zn atoms serving as adsorption site for oxygen-bound intermediates is believed being responsible for the highest activity methanol catalyst [24]. In [25] it was proposed that copper reduction from a.-m. Cu–Zn mixed oxide occurs by a very peculiar mechanism, which considered that H2 is oxidized to 2 protons, which substitute for a Cu2+ cation in its structural position in the mixed oxide (I) –O–Cu2+–O–+H2 →Cu0 +–OH⋯HO– This proposition allows relating the methanol synthesis mechanism to the well-known mechanism of homogeneous ketone hydrogenation in Broensted acid medium [26]. It could also give an explanation on the role of ZnO as the matrix for redox interaction of copper with hydrogen within the catalytic cycle. The mechanism of copper reduction with hydrogen accumulation as protons, which substitute for a copper cation in its structural position was proved for CuCr2O4 [25,27]. However, no direct proof of this mechanism so far exists for Cu–Zn mixed oxide. In [25], this mechanism was assumed based on the reversibility of the structural transformations during the reduction of copper from the mixed oxide. Indeed, reoxidation of the Cu0/ZnO system results in the restoration of the Cu–Zn mixed oxide structure [16] rather than in the formation of individual copper oxide phase. Before reduction and after reoxidation the copper cations are located in the extended defects of the ZnO structure [17,18], which are kept void in the reduced state. Also, it was shown that the Cu0.08Zn0.92O mixed oxide samples accumulate significant amounts of hydrogen during the reduction [28]. Small angle neutron scattering (SANS) studies were performed using isotope-pure 65Cu and 63Cu samples reduced in H2 and D2 and allowed not only measuring the quantity of hydrogen in the reduced samples, but also estimating the Cu–Cu and Cu–H radial distribution density functions. However, the reduced samples accumulated as much as 6 atoms of hydrogen per atom of copper, which is three-fold the stoichiometry of the proposed redox interaction (I). This obvious discrepancy does not allow attributing this whole hydrogen sorption to the copper reduction by reaction (I) and it also brings up a question on the nature of accumulated hydrogen. Moreover, thermogravimetric (TG) studies of Cu0.08Zn0.92O mixed oxide reduction evidence that the sample looses 1.4wt.% [16], while a gain in weight of ca. 0.2% should correspond to the stoichiometry of Cu2+ reduction by reaction (I). Therefore, the existing data on the Cu–Zn mixed oxide reduction seem being inconsistent and additional studies are necessary for understanding the mechanism of the Cu–Zn methanol catalyst activation. Vibrational spectroscopic methods, including inelastic neutron scattering (INS) were found to be useful for such a work in the case of CuCr2O4 [27]. The present investigation is devoted to studying the reduction mechanism of the Cu–Zn mixed oxide model catalyst by means of ex situ INS and in situ FTIR measurements. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the Cu–Zn mixed oxide sample The sample of a.m.-Cu0.08Zn0.92O mixed oxide was prepared by decomposition at 623K in air of the corresponding mixed hydroxycarbonate with hydrozincite-like structure. The hydroxycarbonate was precipitated from the 10wt.% aqueous solution of Cu2+ and Zn2+ nitrates by Na2CO3 solution at 70°C and pH=7, washed thoroughly by distilled water and dried overnight under IR lamp. The preparation procedure was identical to that used in earlier studies of CuZn mixed oxide structure and catalytic properties [2,7,8,16,18]. 2.2 X-ray diffraction Diffraction patterns were obtained with an X-ray diffractometer X’TRA (Thermo Electron Corporation, Switzerland) using Cu Kα radiation in the 2θ angle range of 15–70° with a step size of 0.02° 2θ. 2.3 Thermal analysis of the Cu–Zn mixed oxide reduction Thermogravimetric studies (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) were performed using Netzsch STA 409 in Ar flow (for calcination) and in H2:Ar (4:1) mixture. DSC measurements in hydrogen flow were performed in Pt-Ir crucibles with pierced lids. Gas flow was purified from traces of oxygen by NiCr catalyst column and from water vapors by silica gel. Evolved gas composition was analyzed by Stanford Research Systems UGA200 mass-spectrometer. Signals at 18amu and 44amu were used to characterize water and carbon dioxide elimination from the sample. The measured data were corrected for buoyancy and DSC baselines. The temperature calibration of the thermocouple was performed prior to the measurements. Thermal curves data were processed using Netzsch Thermokinetics 3 software in order to obtain model free kinetic parameters data as well as to perform best fit modeling. 2.4 Inelastic neutron scattering measurements The INS spectra were recorded with the IN1-BeF spectrometer at the Institut Laue-Langevin (ILL), Grenoble, France [29]. A monochromatic beam of neutrons with a variable average nominal energy E I was obtained due to the Bragg reflection from (200) and (220) planes of copper monochromators. We recorded scattered neutrons at an angle of 90° after passing a beryllium filter with a 5meV spectral window at the average energy E F =3.5meV; so the measured excitation energy was equal to ħω = E I − E F = E I −3.5meV, or E I −28.2cm−1. The estimated absolute accuracy is ±10cm−1. Samples of the initial and reduced copper–zinc mixed oxide of volume 19.8–22cm3 (18–23g of sample, depending on the loading density, which ranged from 0.9 to 1.05g/cm3) were placed in an aluminum cylindrical cuvette with a wall thickness of 1mm. The cuvette was connected through the cone-flat joint and Kovar junction with a glass tube for sealing. The initial sample and the sample calcined at 480°C were purged by argon, the reduced samples were obtained by consequent calcination in Ar at 350°C followed by hydrogen treatment at 200°C for 4h or at 480°C for 1h, they were sealed under hydrogen flow after cooling. One more sample was calcined at 350°C, then reduced at 200°C and later reoxidized at 250°C in 0.5–1% O2 in Ar. This sample was sealed under flowing Ar. Note that the samples were not exposed to air between calcination and reductive treatments. Spectra were taken when the temperature of the sample attained ca. 40K to decrease parasitic processes of multiphonon neutron scattering. 2.5 In situ FTIR studies The FTIR studies were performed using a Varian FTIR 800 spectrometer. The sample of a.m.-Cu0.08Zn0.92O mixed oxide was pressed into a thin pellet (ca. 0.2mm) and put into the FTIR cell fitted with CaF2 windows. The cell was equipped with a heating furnace and connected to the vacuum setup via glass tubing. The gas phase composition was monitored by a SRS QMS 200 (Stanford Research Systems, USA) mass-spectrometer connected to the setup through the calibrated diaphragm orifice. McLeod manometers were used for absolute calibration of the MS signal. After sample loading, the gas was evacuated down to 10−2 Pa and the sample was treated at 250°C in vacuum for 70h. Then the sample was cooled down to 145°C and a reference FTIR spectrum was recorded. The interaction of the sample with hydrogen (660Pa) was monitored by recording FTIR spectra while gradually increasing the temperature up to 205°C. In the isothermal hydrogen desorption series, after the sample treatment in vacuum at 250°C, it was cooled down to the necessary temperature (190–230°C) and exposed to 100–500Pa of H2. Then hydrogen was gradually evacuated while periodically recording FTIR spectra. The spectra were compared with a reference spectrum, recorded before hydrogen was fed. 3 Results 3.1 Structure of mixed oxide under the study The Cu0.08Zn0.92O mixed oxide calcined at 623K was shown to have defective ZnO wurtzite-like structure. The diffraction patterns closely reproduce those reported earlier for similar a-m. Cu–Zn oxides [2,16]. Fig. 1 illustrates the diffraction data on the sample under study in comparison with pure ZnO and CuO, prepared by calcination at 623K of the corresponding pure hydroxycarbonates with hydrozincite and malachite structures. All diffraction peaks maxima of Cu0.08Zn0.92O mixed oxide coincide to those of ZnO .The diffraction lines of CuO are absent. The lattice parameters of the Cu0.08Zn0.92O mixed oxide are slightly shifted to а =3.2517(5)Å, с =5.2093(7)Å with respect to pure ZnO oxide having а =3.2535(8)Å and с =5.2138(9)Å. Also, diffraction data analysis shows that addition of Cu2+ cations to the oxide leads to the anisotropic decrease in the coherent scattering domain size in the [001] direction. Analysis of the diffraction peaks shape and width allows concluding on the distortion of the oxide structure in the (001) plane with paracrystallinity factor of 1.1% [30]. Paracrystalline distortion is plausibly related to the extended defects in the wurtzite structure, which was earlier observed by means of HRTEM [16]. 3.2 Thermal analysis of the Cu–Zn mixed oxide reduction and kinetic parameters of the process Curves 1 in Fig. 2 show the TG and DSC data related to the reduction of Cu0.08Zn0.92O oxide calcined at 350°C in an inert gas flow. The exothermal weight loss of ca. 1.1wt.% occurs in two steps at ca. 145 and 160°C, when the temperature is raised at 10K/min rate. It is noteworthy that these curves differ a lot from those obtained for the reduction of the sample which was exposed to air for a long period of time (e.g. several days) after calcination (see curve 2). Bigger weight loss (ca. 1.5wt.%), higher characteristic temperatures and different peak shapes are evident and may be related to the difference in anionic composition of the oxide, which can absorb water and CO2 from air, increasing the content of admixing anions in the structure. The difference in weight loss is almost equal to the value of weight loss by the air-exposed sample during its calcination in argon up to 350°C. The consequent mild oxidation in 0.1% O2 flow does not show weight gain, nor reduction in hydrogen flow shows such a significant weight loss: at the first oxidation–reduction (OR) cycle the sample was found to lose ca. 0.43wt.% during oxidation (endothermic effect with maximal rate at 215°C) and ca. 0.37wt.% during the consequent reduction (exothermic process with maximal rate at 140°C); at the second cycle the weight changes were measured as −0.37 and −0.33wt.%, correspondingly, and at the third cycle they were −0.34 and −0.24wt.%. Finally, the treatment in hydrogen upto 500°C showed weight loss of 1.3wt.% with maximal rate at ca. 420°C, which agrees to earlier thermal data on Cu–Zn oxide reduction [16]. Total weigh loss of the reduced sample within this R(OR)3 series was found as 4.48wt.%. Please note, that according to earlier in situ XRD [16] and EXAFS [18] studies a similar R(OR) n treatment results in reversible formation of metallic copper phase epitaxially bound to defective ZnO and its disappearance accompanied with restoration of Cu–Zn mixed oxide structure, while reduction at above 400°C causes irreversible formation of metallic copper particles separate from regular ZnO phase. The thermal curves of reduction measured at different heating rates (see Fig. S1) allow estimating the kinetic parameters. Dependencies of the DSC maxima temperatures on the heating rate follow nicely the Kissinger law [31] for both samples. However, the estimated activation energies are very different and range from 44kJ/mole for the sample exposed to air before reduction (further denoted as EA) to 105kJ/mole for the sample calcined just before the reduction (denoted further as “just calcined,” JC). Ozawa–Flynn–Wall (OFW) iso-conversional model-free kinetic analysis [32,33] leads to similar values of the effective activation energies (OFW-plots are present in Fig. S1). Impact of reduction extent of the sample EA upon the effective activation energy is small, it decreases from 46±2 to 41±3kJ/mol, which closely reproduces the data of [34] on the reduction of Cu–Zn (1:1) oxide. Reduction of the JC sample is characterized by monotonously increasing effective activation energy from 105 to 135kJ/mol and correspondingly increasing preexponential factor. A linear relation is observed between lg A and E eff – the so-called isokinetic effect (also known as compensation effect), which was earlier described for reduction of some Cu-containing oxides in [35,36], this correlation is shown in Fig. S2. Please note that the further reported data on the Cu0.08Zn0.92O reduction by means of inelastic neutron spectroscopy (INS) and FT-IR spectroscopy correspond to the just-calcined Cu0.08Zn0.92O-JC sample. Cu0.08Zn0.92O-EA sample was not studied by these methods. 3.3 Vibrational spectra of Cu–Zn mixed oxide and their evolution during reduction and reoxidation 3.3.1 INS data The inelastic neutron scattering spectra display several peaks (see Fig. 3 ). The INS spectrum of the initial a.m.-Cu0.08Zn0.92O sample (curve 1) exhibits 7 bands having maxima at ca. 162, 452(strong), 545, 850 (broad), 980, 1710 (weak, broad)cm−1 and 3500cm−1 (weak, broad). The integral intensity of scattering by the initial a.m.-Cu0.08Zn0.92O sample is 3.5 times higher than that by the sample calcined at 480°C (curve 5 in Fig. 3). This decrease in intensity is attributed to the removal of the ad-anions from the ZnO structure during the calcination at elevated temperature. The plausible ad-anions in the initial sample are OH− groups and carbonates CO3 2−, their amount can be estimated in terms of H2O and CO2 interacting with the oxide. Considering the neutron scattering cross-section of the naturally occurring hydrogen isotope mixture σ(H)=82.02 barns/atom, and also σ(C)=5.551, σ(O)=4.232, σ(Zn)=4.131, and σ(Cu)=8.03 barns/atom [37], it is possible to estimate the cross sections of H2O as 168.3 barns/molecule (i.e. of 84.15 barns/atom of H added), of CO2– as 14.02 barns/molecule and for anionically pure Cu0.08Zn0.92O σ =8.67 barns/(stoichiometric unit). The scattering of all the anionic admixtures is ca 2.5×8.67=21.7 barns/(stoichiometric MeO unit). Taking into account that the weigh change of the air exposed sample Cu0.08Zn0.92O-EA during thermal treatment up to 700°C in argon never exceeded 7wt.%, we can suppose that less than 10% of anions in the initial sample are carbonates, this will only contribute 1.37 barns/(stoichiometric MeO unit) to the scattering cross-section. The amount of H in the initial a.m.-Cu–Zn oxide is, therefore, ca. 1 H atom per 4 MeO units or per 2 cell units of wurtzite-like structure. The INS spectrum of the sample after calcination at 480°C (curve 5) contains the bands at 162, 452, and 545cm−1 with almost the same intensity as in the spectrum of the initial sample, while the scattering in the range 650–1100cm−1 is very weak and corresponds to multiphonon processes. It is therefore reasonable to assign the bands at 162, 452 and 545cm−1 to the vibrations of the ZnO lattice (E 2, E 1 and A 1 optic modes according to earlier Raman [38] and INS [39] studies), while the bands at 850, 980, 1710 and 3500cm−1 correspond to the local vibrational modes of OH−and H−anionic admixtures of ZnO. Reduction of the sample at 200°C (curve 2 in Fig. 3) results in a significant (2.5 times) increase of the background and in a proportional increase of the intensity of the three discussed bands above, at 850, 980 and 1710cm−1. The band at 850cm−1 is resolved into two bands at ca. 808 and 881cm−1. The increment of these bands is attributed to the heterolytic dissociation of molecular hydrogen over ZnO and to the formation of hydroxyl (δ Zn-O-H =880cm−1, ν Zn-O-H at ca. 3500cm−1) and hydride (δ Zn-H at 808cm−1, ν Zn-H at 1710cm−1) species. Such an assignment agrees with earlier [40,41] and recent [42] IR spectroscopic studies of pure ZnO in hydrogen. Also a previous INS study [39] of the ZnO–H2 system reported δ Zn-H at 829cm−1 and ν Zn-H at 1665cm−1 ; these values are close to the positions of the discussed features. Besides, the reduction at 200°C leads to the appearance of seven intense bands at <90, ca. 262, 600–650, 1290, 1480, 3030, and 3350cm−1, and shoulders at ca. 1100 and 1370cm−1, which should be attributed to at least three different H-containing species. Reoxidation of the sample (curve 3 in Fig. 3) results in the vanishing of these bands, the spectrum approaching that of the sample before reduction (curve 1), in agreement with the earlier reported reversibility of the reduction after reoxidation by low pressure of O2 [16,17]. The difference between the scattered intensities measured for the reduced and calcined in Ar at 480°C samples corresponds to approx. 1.8 H atoms per a (2MeO) cell unit of wurtzite-like structure. Therefore, the hydrogen treatment at 200°C is accompanied by the absorption of ca. 1.3 hydrogen atoms per a (2MeO) cell unit of wurtzite. This quantity accords earlier SANS data [28]. On the contrary, the reduction at high temperatures (480°C) results in the almost total removal of all hydrogen-containing species. The spectrum (curve 4 in Fig. 3) approaches that of the sample calcined at 480°C in the absence of hydrogen, but having a slightly higher scattered intensity around 650cm−1. Among the INS bands of the reduced sample, the intense narrow peak at 262cm−1 and the shoulders at 1100 and 1370cm−1 have to be assigned to formate species. According to [43,44], a sharp intense band in the range 208–225cm−1 is observed in the neutron scattering spectra of formates on copper oxide surfaces and corresponds to the torsional mode of formate bridging two Cu atoms. Some shift to higher frequency was observed for bulk anhydrous copper formate. Therefore, the band position at 262cm−1 may indicate that the observed formate species are located in the bulk of the ZnO structure. The less intense bands at 1100 and 1370cm−1 correspond to π o-p(C–H) and δ i-p(C–H) vibrations of formate, respectively. The C–H stretching contributes to the intense broad band at 3050cm−1. Also, librational modes of formate species may contribute to the scattering at ca. 600–700cm−1 [43]. Also, CO and COO vibrations of carbonate, bicarbonate, carboxylate and formate species can contribute to the INS spectra, however, the intensities of these features are by an order of magnitude less than of the discussed above hydrogen-related vibrations. Other intense bands at ca. 980, 1290, and 1480cm−1 are probably due to bending modes of hydroxyl groups with different hydrogen bonding strength, while the scattering above 3000cm−1 is due to their stretching. The scattering at ca. 650cm−1 may be due to the librations of H–O–H groups (two geminal protons at one O2−anion near the cation vacancy in the ZnO lattice), similar to those observed in the reduced copper chromite [27]. The relation of the observed species to the process of the copper cations reduction was clarified by means of in situ FTIR studies. 3.3.2 FTIR data on the interaction of H2 The FTIR spectrum of initial oxide measured at 140°C in vacuum (see Fig. 4 ) contains a group of rather intense unresolved bands in the range of 1250–1530cm−1 with maxima at ca 1385 and 1480cm−1 and a shoulder at ca. 1330cm−1. Frost and Hales [45] reported that the bands at 1505, 1383 and 1338cm−1 are characteristic of hydrozincite hydroxycarbonate, while a number of bands in the range from 1330 to 1474cm−1 are characteristic of smithsonite Zn carbonate. Therefore the wide adsorption band can be attributed to ν 3 assymetric stretching modes of carbonate species in the structure of the Cu–Zn oxide, which contains both CO3 2− and OH− residual ad-anions in the structure of the oxide. Weak bands having maxima at 1210, 2820, 2880 and 2920cm−1 have to be ascribed to C–H vibrations of hydrocarbon contamination. Heating of the oxide sample in 660Pa of H2 leads to a rise of IR absorption by the sample. Fig. 4 shows the FTIR differential spectra which were processed using the FTIR spectrum of the oxide sample at 140°C in vacuum as a background curve. The significant ascent of the background in the higher wavelength range is definitely the tail of the fundamental absorption by metallic copper particles. In that range, there are a number of resonant absorption bands. In accordance to INS, FTIR shows absorption bands of at least 2 types of OH (ν OH(1) =3450cm−1, ν OH(2) =3250cm−1, δ OH(2) =1430cm−1, δ OH(1) <1000cm−1) appearing during the treatment of the sample in hydrogen. It is noteworthy that the intensities of OH(2) vibrations correlate with the slope of the background, i.e. to the Cu reduction extent. The appearance of the band at 3250cm−1 during the reduction of the Cu/ZnO system was earlier reported [46,47]. Significant red shift of this band may indicate extremely strong hydrogen bonding, however small bandwidth of ca. 50cm−1 is unusual. The low energy of the stretching mode is plausibly due to location of these hydroxyls within the structure of the oxide with oxygen atom of hydroxyl bound to two or more cationic positions rather than at the surface. For pure ZnO powder, the stretching modes of surface hydroxyl species are above 3400cm−1. Water adsorption over ZnO surfaces should generate OH-groups with stretchings at 3620 ( ( 000 1 ¯ ) plane of ZnO), 3639, 3656 and 3672cm−1 ( ( 10 1 ¯ 0 ) plane of ZnO) [48]. Therefore, the discussed changes in the FTIR spectrum during the reduction of the Cu–Zn oxide in hydrogen cannot be assigned to the primary process of water formation followed by its readsorption over the ZnO surface. Formates (ν C–H at 2850 and 2915cm−1, ν as (O–C–O) at 1550, δ C–H and ν s (O–C–O) at 1360, and π C–H at 1070cm−1) first appear, but later vanish simultaneously to the growth of the pair of vibration bands of gaseous CO2 (at ca. 2350cm−1). Appearance of formates occurs at the expense of carbonates, which is shown by simultaneously decreasing the intensity of adsorption at 1320 and 1520cm−1. Similar conversion of carbonates to formates during reduction of Cu/ZnO precipitated catalyst was reported in [46]. The band at 1550cm−1 does not disappear together with the other mentioned bands; also, the band at 1430cm−1 is too intense for attributing it exclusively to the hydroxyl bendings. It looks reasonable to propose that some carboxylate species contribute to FTIR in this range by ν asOCOand ν sOCOvibrations. According to [49], the bands at 1420cm−1 (νasOCO) and 1580cm−1 (νasOCO) of M+-COO carboxylates form by adsorption of CO over CuO/ZnO system and do not desorb even 238°C. Further removal of these oxocarbon species during the consequent (OR) cycles may be responsible for the weight loss, which we observed by thermal analysis. 3.3.3 Effect of hydrogen pressure and temperature on the FTIR absorption band at 3250cm−1 Evacuation of hydrogen from the cell leads to vanishing of the band at 3250cm−1 from the FTIR spectrum and to decreasing intensity of the band at 1430cm−1, which therefore should partially be ascribed to δ OH(2). The effect of hydrogen pressure on the intensity of the absorption band at 3250cm−1 was measured in a special isothermal desorption experiments and is shown in Fig. 5 . From this plot it follows that there is an equilibrium between gaseous H2 and OH-groups with ν OH(2) at 3250cm−1 . Trends become linear in coordinates θ/(1− θ) vs. PH2 ½ (see Fig. 6 ) and, therefore, they obey the Langmuir equation (1) θ 2 ( 1 − θ ) 2 = K P H 2 for the reaction: (II) H2 +2↔2OH− and a dihydrogen molecule reversibly transforms to two protons, which are absorbed by the oxide. 2 2 Here θ is the ratio of the integral intensity of the band at 3250cm−1 to the maximal observed intensity of this band in the experimental series. Within the applied Langmuir model, the value of θ corresponds to the fraction of copper atoms reduced and substituted by protons. The value of (1− θ) corresponds to the fraction of copper atoms in their oxidized state, Cu2+, within the extended defects of the ZnO structure. Since H2 is oxidized to 2H+, some species should accept electrons. Taking into account the correlation of OH−content and copper reduction extent, the reaction (II) should be completed as (IIa) H2+2O2− +Cu2+ ↔Cu0+2 OH− which is equivalent to Eq. (I). Using vant Hoff equation (2) d ln K d T = Δ r H ° R T 2 it is possible to roughly estimate the standard enthalpy and entropy of the reaction Δ r H°≈−110±10kJ/(molH2), Δ r S°≈−140±20J/(molH2 K). 4 Discussion 4.1 Nature of accumulated hydrogen We have proved the SANS data of Trounov et al. [28], that indeed Cu0.08Zn0.92O mixed oxide accumulates up to 1wt.% of hydrogen during the reductive treatment. However, only part of hydrogen absorbs due to copper reduction. Several processes occur giving different hydrogen species, which we tentatively summarize in Table 1 . Since the heterolytic sorption of H2 by zinc oxide was reported several times and thoroughly discussed earlier in [40,50,51] and many other articles, we will not discuss this process here. Two other processes are worth discussing in more details. 4.2 Formate species. Carbonate decomposition in the presence of hydrogen FTIR data show that the process of carbonate ad-anions decomposition with CO2 elimination occurs in parallel to copper reduction. Please note that the Cu–Zn oxide was pretreated in vacuum at 250°C for 70h. Therefore CO2 desorption only proceeds in the presence of hydrogen. The appearance and further vanishing of the bands attributed to formate species allows to conclude that the CO3 2−decomposition occurs by a two-stage scheme (III) CO3 2− +H2 →HCOO− +OH− (IV) HCOO− +OH− →CO2 +H2 +O2− Hydrogenation of carbonate species to formates (III) was shown in several works, see e.g. [53]. The decomposition of formates by route (IV) was many times shown earlier, e.g. for ZnO in [54] and for the ZnO/ZrO2 system in [55]. More recently CO2 elimination from Cu–Zn (7:3) mixed oxide samples during their reduction was detected by MS-EGA and reported in Ph.D. thesis by Kurr [56]. The maximal rate of carbon dioxide release was attained simultaneously with the maximal rate of hydrogen consumption and water elimination. 3 3 In our present study, we have not detected any increase in MS signal at 18amu during treatment in hydrogen. Water elimination found in [56] corresponds to the reduction of the air-exposed sample ((Cu,Zn)O-EA); also since the copper-rich Cu–Zn (7:3) oxide is partially ex-rosasite, water also may form by the reduction of CuO derived from rosasite hydroxycarbonate. It is noteworthy that formate species are often considered to be the pivotal intermediates for methanol formation, and that the reaction (IV) is the reverse one to the plausible first step of methanol synthesis from CO2 and H2 (V) CO2 +H2 +O2− →HCOO− +OH− According to Fujitani et al. [57], the amount of formate species determines the rate of the reaction, since the relation between θ HCOO and θ Zn is similar to that between TOF and θ Zn. Several works [58,59] concluded that one of the several elementary steps involved in further hydrogenation of formate to methanol must be rate limiting. Therefore, the preceding reaction steps have to be equilibrated in the reaction conditions, including the step (V) ↔ (IV). In our FT-IR studies, we observe two bands at 2850 and 2915cm−1, which can be assigned to ν(C–H) of bidentate and unidentate formate species at Cu sites [47,52]. Formate species on ZnO should have ν(C–H) at 2870–2900cm−1 [60–62], which we do not observe. Since a carbonate is initially related to the anion-modified ZnO structure, the formate should first form on ZnO. The observation of Cu-bound species in our experiment means that these formates are mobile and can easily diffuse to the copper sites. This speculation argues for the methanol synthesis mechanisms which consider an activation of CO2 on ZnO as formate and its further transfer to the metallic copper surface or Cu–ZnO interface [63] for final hydrogenation to methanol. However, in methanol synthesis conditions, formate species can as well be synthesized on the metallic copper surface from CO2 and H2 (see e.g. [64]). 4.3 Redox interaction of H2 and Cu2+ and substitution of protons for Cu2+ The vibrational spectroscopies data give conclusive proof to the earlier proposition of Yurieva and co-authors. Indeed, the reduction of copper is accompanied by the formation of protons which are absorbed by the oxide structure instead of evolving as water from the sample. The apparent contradiction of this conclusion with the sample weight loss observed during the reduction in the TG thermal curves is resolved by the observation of CO2 elimination from the sample (FTIR bands of gaseous CO2 at 2330 and 2360cm−1) due to the consequent formation of formates and their decomposition during the thermal treatment of the sample in hydrogen at elevated temperatures. The weight loss, therefore, is due to CO2 elimination from the sample, rather than due to the elimination of water accompanying the copper reduction. The absorbed protons substitute for copper cations in their positions in or near the extended defects of the ZnO structure (the location of copper cations in the Cu–Zn mixed oxide was concluded based on high resolution TEM [16], resonant SAXS [17], and Cu K EXAFS [18]). The reduction of a copper cation results in the oxidation of two hydrogen atoms and the formation of two equivalent OH groups. The estimated standard entropy change for the redox process (IIa) Δ r S°≈−140±20J/(molH2 K) is close to the value of the standard entropy of molecular hydrogen ( S 500 K ∘ = 145 .7 J/ ( mol K ) ) , 4 4 Calculated using polynomic coefficients from NIST website webbook.nist.gov/chemistry indicating strongly localized states for the absorbed protons, with an entropy of the two OH groups formed being less than 30J/(molK). Stabilization of these OH groups in the structure of ZnO rather than on the surface follows also from the significant red shift and small bandwidth of the stretching band and is also consistent with a slow rate of OH to OD transformation after the changing H2 to D2 [46]. The two protons may be localized at two different O2− anions or may give single HOH group of two “geminal” protons binding to one O2− anion, as it was concluded for the protons absorbed by the reduced (Cu,H)Cr2O4 structure during a similar reduction of copper chromite [27]. Then, the neutron scattering at 600–650cm−1 may be ascribed to librations of these HOH species. 4.4 Activation energy of Cu2+ reduction The values of the effective activation energy for the reduction of Cu0.08Zn0.92O-JC are above 100kJ/mol. Similarly high values of effective activation energies were observed in [27,65] for the reduction of CuCr2O4, which occurs by reaction (I), but they are much higher than the values reported for many other copper-containing oxides, incl. individual copper oxides [35,66], Cu–Mg mixed oxide [36] and also the (Cu,Zn)O-EA sample in this and other studies [34,67]. The activation energy changes with conversion extent, the pre-exponential factor changes as well, an isokinetic effect is observed: (3) lg k 0 = a E a + b According to [68], such a correlation may be a consequence of a two-stage reaction (VI) R ⟶ 1 – transport stage R ∗ ⟶ 2 – chemical reaction P with different activation energies for the steps (VI-1) (transport step) and (VI-2) (chemical reaction step). The effective constant of such a process follows the well-known equation [69]: (4) 1 k e f f = 1 k 1 + 1 k 2 while the effective activation energy (5) E e f f = k 1 E 2 + k 2 E 1 k 1 + k 2 varies from E 1 to E 2, and the effective pre-exponential factor k 0 follows the trend (3). Taking into account that the activation energy of Cu2+ auto-diffusion in CuO is ca. 150–160kJ/mol [70], the observed isokinetic trends may be due to diffusion limitations on the copper cations (transport step) while the value of E a for the (Cu,Zn)O-JC reduction step proper is ca. 105kJ/mol. Reverting to the discussion on carbonate decomposition via formate intermediates one can note that the reversible process (IV)–(V) occurs simultaneously to reversible processes of copper reduction (IIa). Therefore, it is natural to suppose that it proceeds via equilibrated Cu2+ reduction/oxidation steps: (VII) HCOO− +Cu2+ +O2− ↔CO2 +Cu0 +OH− (IIa) Cu0 +2 OH− ↔Cu2+ +2 O2− +H2 and protons of the discussed OH groups are reactive species, which can participate in the process of CO2 hydrogenation. However the kinetics of this reaction route is plausibly slower, than those with participation of surface hydrogen species because of high activation energy of (IIa) reaction. 4.5 Difference between air-exposed and just-calcined Cu0.08Zn0.92O samples The high activation energy above 100kJ/mol is possibly a characteristic feature of the above discussed Cu2+ reduction mechanism by reaction (IIa). Then the sample Cu0.08Zn0.92O-EA (the one which was exposed to air) is reduced by a different reaction route, since reduction occurs with an effective activation energy of 40–47kJ/mol. According to the TG data in Fig. 2, the EA-sample looses only 0.4wt.% more than the JC-sample during the reduction. Exposure to air changes the anionic composition of the sample by sorption of water and CO2. The difference between EA and JC is small and corresponds to sorption of 0.02 moles of H2O (giving twice more OH−anions) or 8×10−3 moles of CO2 (giving CO3 2− anions) with respect to 1 mole of Me2+ cations in the oxide following the reactions (VIII) O2− +H2O→OH− +OH− (IX) O2− +CO2 →CO3 2− It is surprising that the addition of such a negligible amount of OH−or CO3 2− changes the effective activation energy of copper reduction dramatically. The only explanation we found is to tentatively suppose that these species are located in the extended defects of the ZnO structure, in the close neighborhood of Cu2+ cations giving a Cu2+(OH−)4 flat square coordination shell (VIIIa) O2−–Cu2+–O2− +2 H2O→Cu2+(OH−)4 Then the redox interaction of Cu2+ and H2 proceeding by a conjectural reaction (X) H2 +Cu2+(OH−)4 →Cu0 +[vacancy](OH−)2(HOH)2 which is analogous the reaction (IIa) should be followed by water elimination (XI) Cu0 +[vacancy](OH−)2(HOH)2 →Cu0 +[vacancy](OH−)2 +2 H2O As a consequence of reactions (VIIIa) and (X) + (XI), one obtains reaction (IIa). The final state of the reduced Cu–Zn oxide would be similar for (Cu,Zn)O-EA and (Cu,Zn)O-JC. However, the kinetic parameters for reaction (IIa) would differ from those of the process (X) + (XI), including a higher activation energy. Therefore, it is natural to tentatively suppose that exposure of (Cu,Zn)O to air results in the absorption of water in the extended defects of (Cu,Zn)O, which changes the composition of the first coordination shell of Cu2+ cations and affects the kinetic parameters of the reduction process. The schematic presentation of the Cu2+ reduction routes for EA and JC samples is shown in Fig. 7 . Difference in composition of the first coordination shell of Cu2+ cations of EA and JC samples agrees well with the change of Cu2+ local neighborhood after consequent treatments in H2 flow and in 50Pa of O2 (reduction–oxidation or RO treatment) which was observed in ref. [18] by EXAFS. There it was concluded that initial air-exposed (EA) mixed oxide contains copper mainly as ultra-small clusters comprising less than 4 Cu2+ cations in distorted octahedral coordination, while after RO and RORO treatments (the sample close to JC one) Cu2+ clusters have the stripe-like geometry with a significant length of a stripe, i.e. they are better ordered than those of the initial Сu0.08Zn0.92O-EA. 5 Conclusions Cu0.08Zn0.92O mixed oxide prepared by calcination of hydroxicarbonate with aurichalcaite structure contains significant amount of ad-anions, including carbonates and hydroxyl groups. When treated in H2 at 200°C, it accumulates upto 6H/Cu, as formates, hydroxyl groups and hydride anions. We can conclude that the reduction of Cu2+ in (Cu,Zn)O mixed oxide occurs via a redox interaction with H2 and absorption of protons as OH−-groups with ν =3250cm−1 and δ ≈1430–1480cm−1 according to the reversible reaction Cu2+ +2 O2− +H2 ↔Cu0+2 OH− The observed weight loss during the reduction is due to the decomposition of carbonate ad-anions to CO2 via formate intermediates in the presence of hydrogen. Isothermal desorption studies allow estimating the standard enthalpy and entropy of Cu2+ reduction as Δ r H°≈−110±10kJ/(molH2), Δ r S°≈−140±20J/(molH2 .K). The process is characterized by high activation energy of ca. 105kJ/mol. The absorbed protons are reactive species, which can participate in the process of CO2 hydrogenation over Cu–Zn oxides. However the kinetics of this reaction route is plausibly slower, than those with participation of surface hydrogen species. coredata.dc:description: Interaction of hydrogen with model Cu–Zn methanol synthesis catalyst prepared by decomposition of mixed hydroxicarbonate is studied by inelastic neutron scattering, in situ FTIR/MS, and thermal analysis. Reduced (Cu0.08,Zn0.92)O mixed oxide accumulates 6H/Cu, mainly as hydride, hydroxyl and formate species. The reduction of copper in the (Cu,Zn)O mixed oxide occurs via a reversible redox interaction with H2 and absorption of protons as OH−-groups with ν =3250cm−1 and δ ≈1430–1480cm−1. Kinetic and thermodynamic parameters of this process are evaluated. The weight loss during the reduction is due to the decomposition of the residual carbonate groups to CO2 via formate intermediates, which occurs in the presence of hydrogen. Exposure of (Cu,Zn)O to air prior to the reduction strongly affects the kinetic parameters of the reduction process.
coredata.dc:title: Interaction of hydrogen with Cu–Zn mixed oxide model methanol synthesis catalyst
